newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippine grain buyers sidelined by high prices.
newsitem.headline: Philippine grain buyers sidelined by high prices.

text.p: Philippine grain importers will probably be glued to the sidelines next week and adopt a wait-and-see attitude because of high prices of U.S. wheat and soybeans, traders said on Friday.
"We will be shying away from the market," said an official from a local flour mill in Manila.
"We've talked to the millers and most of them are leaving for the holidays," said one trader, refering to the long Easter holidays in the Philippines next week.
With U.S. wheat prices so high, Philippine flour mills have turned to supplies from Canada, where they recently bought 35,000 tonnes of Canadian spring and soft wheat for May shipment.
Philippine firms buy most of their wheat and soybean from the United States. On average, they buy about 20,000 tonnes of soybean and some 120,000 tonnes of wheat a month.
The National Food Authority (NFA) said it expects no further negotiations for any rice or corn imports next week.
It said a ship from Vietnam had begun unloading 10,500 tonnes of rice while a vessel from China began unloading 27,198 tonnes of yellow corn in Manila.
Another ship from Vietnam was scheduled to start unloading its cargo of 7,300 tonnes of rice on Sunday.
The Department of Trade and Industry said prices of local hard flour remained unchanged at 290 pesos per 25-kilogram bag while soft flour was seen steady at 260 pesos per 25 kg bag.
The average retail price of yellow corn in the local market slipped from 10.79 pesos a kg to 10.77 while white corn also dropped slightly to 10.94 pesos from 10.95 per kg.
